In the United Kingdom, '''USR''', the ''' Universities Statistical Record ''' consists of records of undergraduate students on courses of one academic year or more; postgraduate students on courses of one academic year or more; academic and related staff holding regular salaried appointments, and finance data for all UK universities.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.esds.ac.uk/findingData/snDescription.asp?sn=3455 |title=Universities' Statistical Record, 1984/85-1993/94 : Finance |publisher=UK Data Service |date=1995 |website= |access-date=1 December 2016}}</ref> It was compiled by [[Universities Central Council on Admissions|UCCA]], the Universities Central Council on Admissions from its formation in 1961 until its merger with PCAS (Polytechnics Central Admissions Service) to form [[UCAS]] in 1993.<ref> {{cite book |last=Kay |first=Ronald |date=June 1985 |title=UCCA: Its Origins And Development 1950-1985 |publisher=UCCA |isbn=0-900951-56-7}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=University Grants Committee |year=1978 |title=Universities' statistical record - an explanatory note |publisher= Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals |id=dewey 378/.001/82}}</ref>
The [[Higher Education Statistics Agency]] (HESA) became the official agency for the collection, analysis and dissemination of quantitative information about higher education in 1993. http://www.hesa.ac.uk/index.php/content/view/4/54/ It was set up by agreement between the relevant government departments, the higher education funding councils and the universities and colleges in 1993, following the White Paper “Higher Education: a new framework”, which called for more coherence in HE statistics, and the 1992 Higher and Further Education Acts, which established an integrated higher education system throughout the United Kingdom.
==Main topics== Finance: income and expenditure; university; cost centre. The Finance dataset contains details of income and expenditure for all of the UK universities. These data are contained in a series of files for each year.
Student load: undergraduate, postgraduate (taught course or research); cost centre.
==Coverage== Time Period Covered: 1964 - 1993 Country: United Kingdom
==Methodology== The Finance data were collected from annual returns based on the university financial year (August to July). Method of Data Collection: Annual returns from each university were collated by UCCA.

{{good article}} {{Use American English|date=May 2013}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox television | show_name = You Are the One | image = Sosmivida.jpg | caption = The main characters, [[Natalia Oreiro]] and [[Facundo Arana]] | genre = {{Plainlist| * [[Drama]] * [[Humor]] * [[Romance film|Romance]] * Comedy }} | creator = [[Adrián Suar]] | director = {{Plainlist| * Rodolfo Antúnez * Jorge Bechara }} | writer = {{Plainlist| * Ernesto Korovsky * Sebastián Parrotta }} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Natalia Oreiro]] * [[Facundo Arana]] * [[Carla Peterson (actress)|Carla Peterson]] * [[Carlos Belloso]] * [[Mónica Ayos]] }} | theme_music_composer = Natalia Oreiro, original song by [[Gilda]] | opentheme = "Corazon Valiente" | endtheme = "Corazon Valiente" | composer = Natalia Oreiro | country = Argentina | language = Spanish | num_episodes = 230 | executive_producer = Adrián González | producer = {{Plainlist| * Mariana Petraglia * Julieta Martinelli }} | editor = {{Plainlist| * Alejandro Alem * Alejandro Parysow }} | location = [[Buenos Aires]], Argentina | cinematography = {{Plainlist| * Pablo Storino * Jorge Fernández }} | runtime = 60 minutes | network = [[El Trece (Argentina)|El Trece]] | first_run = | first_aired = {{Start date|2006|1|16}} | last_aired = {{End date|2007|1|9}} | website = http://www.pol-ka.com.ar/sosmivida/index.htm }}
'''''You Are the One''''' ({{lang-es|Sos mi vida}}, [[Literal translation|lit.]]: "You Are My Life") is a 2006 Argentine [[romantic comedy]] television series, directed by Rodolfo Antúnez and Jorge Bechara and broadcast by [[El Trece (Argentina)|El Trece]] between January 16, 2006, and January 9, 2007. It is the second telenovela starring [[Facundo Arana]] and [[Natalia Oreiro]] as lead actors. The production included many location shootings, even during the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]] in Germany, and many guest stars.
The plot follows the love story of Martín Quesada, an affluent businessman, and Esperanza Muñoz, a struggling female boxer who becomes his personal assistant. During its broadcast its overall rating averaged 26.9 points.<ref name="Eterno">{{cite web |url= http://edant.clarin.com/diario/2007/01/11/espectaculos/c-01101.htm|title= Sos mi vida: el fenómeno del amor eterno|trans-title= Sos mi vida: the phenomenon of eternal love|language= Spanish|author= Silvina Lamazares|date= January 11, 2007|publisher= Clarín|accessdate=August 28, 2012}}</ref> It was critically acclaimed, and won four [[Martín Fierro Awards]] and three [[Clarín Awards]]. It was sold to more than 40 countries and had remakes in Mexico, Poland and Portugal.
==Premise== The [[telenovela]] was produced by [[Pol-ka]] based on a premise by [[Adrián Suar]], which he formulated nearly six months before the show's premiere, after discussion with his partner Javier Blanco y Tevah.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.castingportena.com.ar/notas/sec14ant.asp?id=184|title= Planeta Pol-Ka|trans-title= Planet Pol-Ka|language= Spanish|author= Natalia Trzenko|work= La Nación|accessdate=August 28, 2012}}</ref> The premise involves a rich businessman and former Formula 1 racing driver who falls in love with a poor woman looking for work in his emporium. Suar requested scripts from Ernesto Korovsky and Sebastian Parrotta, the authors of ''Gasoleros'' and ''El sodero de mi vida'', and ''[[Hombres de honor]]'' and ''[[Padre Coraje]]'' respectively. The program was directed by Daniel De Felippo and Rodolfo Antúnez and produced by César Markus González. Most of the filming was done in the Pol-ka studio at the [[Colegiales]] neighborhood, using outdoor scenes unconventional for the genre.<ref name="Eterno"/>
The telenovela features [[Facundo Arana]] and [[Natalia Oreiro]], who both appeared in the successful telenovela ''[[Muñeca Brava]]'', as lead actors. The relationship between the two was more than professional; Facundo Arana had spontaneously been offered a guest appearance on the Russian series ''A ritmo de tango'' starring Oreiro.<ref name="Quimica">{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/772619-una-pareja-con-quimica|title= Una pareja con química|trans-title= A couple with chemistry|language= Spanish|date= January 16, 2006|work= La Nación|accessdate=August 28, 2012}}</ref> Both actors agreed to appear in ''You Are the One'' on the condition that they worked together. As a result, the program design was decided only after both were confirmed in the leading roles.<ref name="Quimica"/> Oreiro delayed filming proposals in Israel, Spain, and Uruguay, and the recording of her fourth music album to join the project.<ref name="Rionegro">{{cite web |url= http://www1.rionegro.com.ar/arch200601/16/c16a01.php|title= Oreiro y Arana juntos en 'Sos mi vida'|trans-title= Oreiro and Arana together in "You Are The One"|language= Spanish|date= January 16, 2006|publisher= Río Negro Online|accessdate=August 28, 2012}}</ref> As in ''Muñeca Brava'', the narrative of ''You Are the One'' revolves around a wealthy suitor and a poor woman, but unlike the former program it does not concentrate all the characters on a single narrative context. ''You Are the One'' organizes two contexts for both the rich and the poor, each one with its own characteristic locations and supporting characters.<ref name="Quimera">{{cite web |url= http://edant.clarin.com/diario/2006/02/12/espectaculos/c-00811.htm|title= Quimera de amor entre dos mundos|trans-title= Impossible love between two worlds|language= Spanish|author= María Iribarren|date= February 12, 2006|publisher= Clarín|accessdate=August 28, 2012}}</ref>
[[File:Buenos Aires-La Boca-P2070003.JPG|thumb|left|Houses of [[La Boca]] neighbourhood, with their characteristic style. The tenement of the series was modeled after it.]]
Natalia Oreiro plays Esperanza Muñoz, a female boxer nicknamed "La Monita". Oreiro was inspired by the singer [[Gilda (singer)|Gilda]] to outline the character's personality.<ref name="Gilda">{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/838297-gilda-es-cultura|title= Gilda es cultura|trans-title= Gilda is culture|language= Spanish|author= Sebastián Ramos|date= September 7, 2006|work= La Nación|accessdate=August 28, 2012}}</ref> The main location is a tenement in the neighborhood of [[La Boca]] where Esperanza lives with other characters. Her adoptive mother Nieves lives with Enrique "Quique" Ferreti, her natural son and Esperanza's childhood boyfriend. The writers drafted Quique's general outlines; Belloso defined most of his personality, including the relationship with Esperanza{{mdash}}which is halfway between engagement and brotherhood{{mdash}}and his [[Oedipus complex]] with his mother.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www1.rionegro.com.ar/diario/2006/07/10/20067c10f08.php|title= Carlos Belloso con brillo propio en 'Sos mi vida'|trans-title= Carlos Belloso shines by himself in "You Are The One"|language= Spanish|author= Romina Grosso|date= July 10, 2006|publisher= Río Negro Online|accessdate=August 28, 2012}}</ref> Esperanza trains as a boxer in a neighbourhood gymnasium with Quique, who has a wrestling [[Gimmick (professional wrestling)|gimmick]] as "Commander Ray". Other main characters in the series are actress Nilda Yadhur, known as "The Turk", and Paraguayan janitor Kimberly.<ref name="Quimera"/>
The character of Martín Quesada establishes a context of wealthy characters. Quesada is a businessman and Formula 1 driver, but is not presented as selfish or greedy as is the archetype of entrepreneurs in soap operas. The two locations associated with him are the Quesada Group office, presided over by him, and his home. The office has the characters of Quesada's chief adviser Alfredo Uribe, the secretary Mercedes, and his cousin Miguel Quesada, who serves as vice-president, and the lawyer Felix Perez Garmendia. His girlfriend Constanza Insua and his cousin Debbie are also included. Martín lives with his housekeeper Rosa, Rosa's grandson Tony, and three adopted orphan siblings, José, Laura, and Coqui. Another recurring site is the apartment of Miguel and Debbie, which would be also used as the house of Constanza or Garmendia if needed.<ref name="Quimera"/> {{clear}}
==Plot== [[File:Sosmivida2.jpg|thumb|Supporting characters of the telenovela. From left to right: Alfredo Uribe ([[Alejandro Awada]]), Mercedes ([[Claudia Fontán]]), Enrique "Quique" Ferreti ([[Carlos Belloso]]), Constanza Inzúa ([[Carla Peterson (actress)|Carla Peterson]]) and Miguel Quesada (Marcelo Mazzarello)]]
The story begins during a boxing match of Esperanza Muñoz{{mdash}}nicknamed "Monita"{{mdash}}who has sustained a hand injury. Her manager, Enrique "Quique" Ferreti, is pressuring her to continue fighting, despite her pain. This injury complicates her economic situation, as her boxing provides the only income for her adoptive family, namely Quique and his mother, Maria de las Nieves. Nieves loves Esperanza like her own daughter, and pressures her to marry Quique. Her neighbor Kimberly suggests that Esperanza apply for a job in the Quesada Group, where she works as a janitress. The secretary Mercedes rejects Esperanza due to her violent manners and her dressing style. Martín Quesada, the president of the company, sees Esperanza crying in the street and hires her as his personal assistant.
Martín also meets three orphan siblings, José, Laura, and Coqui, who resisted being adopted by different families. He takes them to his home, and starts the legal proceedings to adopt them. Martín begins to like Esperanza, but his girlfriend Constanza, a cold, manipulative, and malicious woman, is wary of her. Esperanza does not tell Martín about her relations with Quique, instead pretending to be his sister. She also does not tell Martín that she is a boxer. Quique and Constanza begin their own relationship, unknown by most other characters. Martín breaks off his relationship with Esperanza when he sees her goodbye kiss with Quique, as he realizes that she was lying to him.
After the breakup with Esperanza, Martín resumes his romance with Constanza and eventually proposes marriage to her, in order to improve his chances of winning custody of the three siblings. The judge, who thought that Esperanza was a bad influence on the children, gives the adoption to Constanza instead of Martín, forcing him to marry her. Their marriage proves difficult; Constanza is demanding and possessive, and despises the adopted siblings, who hate her as well. Martín finally breaks with Constanza when she pretends to be blind to keep him with her. The children's custody battle delays the divorce, as Martín wants to keep them.
Due to the efforts of Martín's cousin Miguel, the unscrupulous lawyer "Falucho", and Constanza, Martin gradually loses his fortune, his business, and his house. He moves to the Conventillo and works as a taxi driver. Eventually, he recovers everything. A new character, Bárbara, temporarily joins the love triangle of Martín, Esperanza, and Constanza. Constanza gets pregnant by Quique and tries to pass off her son as Martín's, but fails. Martín finally marries Esperanza and has a family with her and the adopted children. Constanza moves in with Quique.
==Production== [[File:080110 schalke arena germany.JPG|thumb|The [[Veltins-Arena]] stadium. An episode featured [[location shooting]] during the Argentina-Serbia and Montenegro match of the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]].]]
The program was directed by Daniel De Felippo and Rodolfo Antúnez, and produced by César Markus González. Most of the filming occurred at the headquarters of Pol-ka in the Colegiales neighborhood. The telenovela took several risks in the creative and production fields, which were mostly successful.<ref name="Eterno"/> The choice of Martín Quesada's background as a Formula 1 driver required an area with a large infrastructure to represent realistic races. For realism, plot scenes set outside Buenos Aires were actually filmed outside the city. There was significant press coverage during the location shooting in Germany, which took place during the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]]. Facundo Arana and Natalia Oreiro played their characters in the [[Veltins-Arena]] stadium during the Argentina-Serbia and Montenegro match. The result of the match{{mdash}}a 6–0 Argentine victory{{mdash}}benefited the filming, and the episode received 31.5 rating points.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://edant.clarin.com/diario/2006/06/22/espectaculos/c-00201.htm|title= Yo te sigo a todas partes |trans-title= I follow you everywhere|language= Spanish|author= Silvina Lamazares |date= June 22, 2006|publisher= Clarín|accessdate=August 28, 2012}}</ref> Location shooting also occurred in the tourist ski resort [[Las Leñas]] in the [[Andes]]. A simulated aircraft crash that left the characters in a jungle was filmed at the [[Pereyra Iraola park]] and an [[Argentine Air Force]] park in Morón.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.diariolarepublica.com.ar/notix/noticia.php?i=116053&f=2006-12-20|title= Martín y la Monita perdidos en la selva |trans-title= Martín and Monita lost in the jungle|language= Spanish|date= December 20, 2006|publisher= La República|accessdate=August 28, 2012}}</ref>
To make her performances as a female boxer look realistic, Oreiro trained regularly with the renowned boxer [[Marcela Acuña]] and her coach Ramón Chaparro.<ref name="Rionegro"/> They taught Oreiro how to stand and move in the ring and how to make various types of strokes, and she underwent cardiovascular and weight training. Acuña commented that Oreiro mastered the basic techniques more quickly than most beginner boxers.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.latigresa.com.ar/prensa/15.asp|title= Muñecas bravas|trans-title= Brave dolls|language= Spanish|author= Marcela Acuña|publisher= Tigresa Acuña press|accessdate=August 28, 2012}}</ref> For this training, Oreiro temporarily gave up her [[vegetarianism|vegetarian]] diet.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.diariodecuyo.com.ar/home/new_noticia.php?noticia_id=137315|title= Las primeras ficciones del verano|trans-title= The first fictions of the summer|language= Spanish|author= Soledad Villarroya|date= January 16, 2006|publisher= Dario de Cuyo|accessdate=August 28, 2012}}</ref> Another plot required the characters to fly a [[Piper Tomahawk]] airplane and make an emergency landing. This was risky filming, and Arana and Oreiro did not use stunt doubles for it.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.infobae.com/notas/nota.php?Idx=253328&idxSeccion=0|title= Arana y Oreiro arriesgan sus vidas|trans-title= Arana and Oreiro risk their lives|language= Spanish|date= May 5, 2006|publisher= Infobae|accessdate=August 28, 2012}}</ref> The scene, which was the first of its kind in a daily Argentine telenovela, required four professional pilots, five special effects experts, and two additional aircraft used for filming the main aircraft from the outside.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://edant.clarin.com/diario/2006/05/13/espectaculos/c-00601.htm|title= Un amor con mucho vuelo|trans-title= A love that flies high|language= Spanish|date= May 13, 2006|publisher= Clarín|accessdate=August 28, 2012}}</ref> Arana was advised by the pilot Alberto Di Giorgio.<ref name="Rionegro"/>
The program's opening theme is [[Gilda (singer)|Gilda]]'s "Corazón Valiente" ({{lang-es|Braveheart}}), sung by Oreiro. It was produced by Toti Gimenez, widower and producer of the late Gilda. Oreiro is a fan of Gilda and chose this song as a homage to mark the 10th anniversary of her death.<ref name="Rionegro"/><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.infobae.com/notas/nota.php?Idx=232324&IdxSeccion=100743|title= Natalia Oreiro homenajeará a Gilda|trans-title= Natalia Oreiro will homage Gilda|language= Spanish|date= January 15, 2006|publisher= Infobae|accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref> She considered including it in her next music CD, but did not record anything afterwards.<ref name="Gilda"/>
===Guest actors=== [[File:Marcela Acuña.jpg|thumb|The boxer [[Marcela Acuña]] trained Natalia Oreiro and appeared as a guest star in the show.]]
The program featured several guest stars, who appeared in secondary or support roles in several episodes. Some guest stars{{mdash}}such as the singers [[Chayanne]], [[Ricky Martin]] and [[Julieta Venegas]]{{mdash}}played themselves within the fiction of the program. Venegas' song "Tu Nombre" is used as a background song in romantic settings. Marcela Acuña appeared twice, playing herself in a match against Oreiro's character.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://old.clarin.com/diario/2006/12/06/espectaculos/c-00403.htm|title= Una pelea entre fierecillas|trans-title= A fight among beasts|language= Spanish|date= December 6, 2006|publisher= Clarín|accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref> The appearance of actress [[Leticia Brédice]] was nominated for the "best cameo in fiction" category at the [[Martín Fierro Awards]]; the prize was given to Nora Cárpena.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/904827-martin-fierro-montecristo-la-mas-nominada|title= Martín Fierro: Montecristo, la más nominada|trans-title= Martín Fierro: Montecristo, the most nominated|language= Spanish|date= April 30, 2007|work= La Nación|accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref> Actress [[Reina Reech]] delayed other projects to take part in the program.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://old.clarin.com/diario/2006/07/14/espectaculos/c-00401.htm|title= Eran pocos... y llegó la reina madre|trans-title= They were few... and the mother queen arrived|language= Spanish|author= Fernanda Longo|date= July 14, 2006|publisher= Clarín|accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref>
===Narration=== The program expanded the usual conventions of the genre by using several types of [[metafiction]], referencing the actors themselves or the nature of the program.<ref name="Eterno"/> An example within the plot is ''Sos mi muqui'', a [[Story within a story|program within the program]] whose characters were based on the show's main characters. The actors' former characters are occasionally referenced in plots that place them in similar contexts than those of older fictions. Martín infiltrated a convent using a habit similar to the one Arana's character in ''[[Padre Coraje]]'' wore, and Esperanza wore clothes similar to those Oreiro's character in ''[[Muñeca Brava]]'' wore when they had to get into a slum.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://edant.clarin.com/diario/2006/03/18/espectaculos/c-00301.htm|title= Oreiro resucitó a Cholito |trans-title= Oreiro resurrected Cholito|language= Spanish|date= March 18, 2006|publisher= Clarín|accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref>
Many actors played minor characters as well as their main roles. Pablo Cedrón played a Paraguayan brother of his character Falucho; both characters were involved in a love triangle with Kimberly. Carlos Belloso was cast as Quique's lost sister, dressed as a woman. Natalia Oreiro, who speaks Russian fluently, took the role of a Russian princess. Facundo Arana played a criminal, a role unlike Martín.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://edant.clarin.com/diario/2006/09/22/conexiones/t-01276371.htm|title= Tuvo un sospechoso cambio de actitud: el bueno de Facundo Arana se sacó la careta (era hora)|trans-title= Suspecting change of attitude: the good Facundo Arana dropped the mask (it was about time)|language= Spanish|author= Lorena Bassani|date= September 22, 2006|publisher= Clarín|accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref> Those scenes did not use special effects; each character was filmed separately without the two characters sharing the screen. The hero of the telenovela marries the villain, contrary to the genre's usual convention in which such a wedding is interrupted or canceled at the last moment.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://edant.clarin.com/diario/2006/07/19/conexiones/t-01236598.htm|title= ¿El mundo se volvió loco? Finalmente, Facundo Arana se casó con su novia|trans-title= Has the world gone mad? Finally, Facundo Arana got married with his girlfriend|language= Spanish|author= Lorena Bassani|date= July 19, 2006|publisher= Clarín|accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref>

==Reception==
===Ratings=== The program was first broadcast in January, a month of low television activity in Argentina because of the summer vacations. Nevertheless, it was highly successful.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1080460-la-television-del-verano|title= La televisión del verano|trans-title= Summer television|language= Spanish|author= Ricardo Marín |date= December 14, 2008|work= La Nación|accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref> The competitor channel [[Telefe]] aired the teen comedy ''[[Alma Pirata]]'', which was rescheduled because of its low ratings,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/823692-los-programas-para-adolescentes-en-baja|title= Los programas para adolescentes, en baja|trans-title= Teen programs, in decline|language= Spanish|author= Carlos Sanzol|date= July 16, 2006|work= La Nación|accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref> and replaced it with the second season of ''[[Casados con Hijos (Argentina)|Casados con Hijos]]''. Both programs had similar ratings until the end of ''Casados con Hijos'' in August.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/832336-a-los-golpes-pero-con-rating|title= A los golpes, pero con rating|trans-title= Fighting, but with rating|language= Spanish|date= August 17, 2006|work= La Nación|accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref> With an average rating of 26.8 points, ''Sos mi vida'' ended as the most watched Argentine television fiction so far;<ref name="amor">{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/874230-el-fin-del-amor-mas-visto-de-la-tv|title= El fin del amor más visto de la TV|trans-title= The end of the most watched love in TV|language= Spanish|date= January 11, 2007|work= La Nación|accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref> it was displaced by the 2009, telenovela ''[[Valientes]]'', which received 27.3 rating points.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://television.com.ar/diario-online/minuto-a-minuto/data/104571/valientes-la-tira-mas-vista-de-pol-ka/#.UEI9c6Ak35Y|title= Valientes, la tira más vista de Pol-Ka|trans-title= Valientes the most seen production of Pol-Ka|language= Spanish|publisher= Television.com.ar|accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref>
===Awards=== [[File:Natalia Oreiro.jpg|thumb|left|[[Natalia Oreiro]] received the [[Martín Fierro Awards|Martín Fierro Award]] for her work.]]
The program was awarded the best TV comedy at the 2006 ceremony of the [[Martín Fierro Awards]], prevailing over ''Casados con hijos'' and ''[[¿Quién es el Jefe?]]''. Facundo Arana received the award for best lead actor in comedy, prevailing over Guillermo Francella, [[Humberto Tortonese]], and [[Nicolás Vázquez]]. Natalia Oreiro won the award for the best lead actress in comedy, prevailing over Florencia Peña, [[Nancy Duplaá]], [[Carmen Barbieri]], and [[Andrea Bonelli]]. [[Alejandro Awada]], [[Marcelo Mazzarello]], and [[Carlos Belloso]] received nominations for supporting comedy actor awards, which was won by Belloso. Similarly, three of five nominations for supporting comedy actress went to [[Carla Peterson (actress)|Carla Peterson]], [[Mónica Ayos]] and [[Claudia Fontán]], but the award went to [[Érika Rivas]] of ''Casados con hijos''. The program was unsuccessfully nominated for best theme song and best guest appearance for [[Leticia Brédice]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.terra.com.ar/canales/tv/160/160798.html|title= Montecristo ganó el Martín Fierro de Oro|trans-title= Montecristo won the golden Martín Fierro award|language= Spanish|date= May 24, 2007|publisher= Terra|accessdate=July 11, 2013}}</ref>
Facundo Arana and Natalia Oreiro were nominated again at the 2007 Martín Fierro Awards. These nominations proved controversial because the program only lasted for a week in 2007, and had no second season, and both actors took a recess from work after it.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1026466-los-premios-martin-fierro-en-medio-de-la-controversia|title= Los premios Martín Fierro, en medio de la controversia|trans-title= The Martín Fierro awards, amid the controversy|language= Spanish|author= Natalia Trzenko|date= July 2, 2008|publisher= a Nación|accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref> Neither of them received an award for those nominations. Oreiro won the newly created award for the best dressed actress of the night, which is not part of the official awards.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1026961-lalola-arraso-en-los-martin-fierro-y-se-llevo-el-oro|title= Lalola arrasó en los Martín Fierro y se llevó el Oro|trans-title= Lalola prevailed in the Martín Fierro and took the Gold one|language= Spanish|author= Azul Cecinini|date= March 2, 2009|work= La Nación|accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref>
At the [[Clarín Awards]] ceremony in late 2006, the program was awarded for the best comedy, prevailing over ''[[Casados con Hijos (Argentina)|Casados con hijos]]'' and ''Alma Pirata''. [[Elías Viñoles]] won the award for best actor, Ornella Fazio was nominated for best female actor; the award was given to María Abadi of ''[[Montecristo (Argentine telenovela)|Montecristo]]''. Unlike the Martín Fierro, the Clarín awards do not distinguish between lead and supporting actors. Belloso was awarded as best comedy actor; Oreiro was nominated and the award was given to Érika Rivas.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://edant.clarin.com/diario/2006/12/19/espectaculos/c-01330664.htm|title= La fiesta que distinguió a lo mejor del espectáculo|trans-title= The party that awarded the best of the spectacle|language= Spanish|date= December 19, 2006|publisher= Clarín|accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref>
===Critical reception=== The ''[[Clarín (Argentine newspaper)|Clarín]]'' newspaper attributes the success of the program to the actors' performances, the subplots, production initiatives, and the original treatment of stories.<ref name="Eterno"/><ref>{{cite web |url= http://edant.clarin.com/diario/2006/02/12/espectaculos/c-00904.htm|title= Terceros en conflicto (o parejas que arden)|trans-title= Conflictive third ones (or couples that burn)|language= Spanish|date= February 12, 2006|publisher= Clarín|accessdate=August 28, 2012}}</ref> The work of the supporting cast was also praised, including Carla Peterson,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://edant.clarin.com/diario/2006/07/06/espectaculos/c-00811.htm|title= Las chicas malas me sientan bien|trans-title= Bad girls suit me fine|language= Spanish|author= Silvina Lamazares|date= July 6, 2006|publisher= Clarín|accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref> Fabiana Garcia Lago,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/782417-una-actriz-en-primer-plano|title= Una actriz en primer plano|trans-title= An actress in the main focus|language= Spanish|author= Natalia Trzenko|date= February 21, 2006|work= La Nación|accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref> and Marcelo Mazzarello.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://edant.clarin.com/diario/2006/02/13/espectaculos/c-00401.htm|title= El hombre que halló su destino|trans-title= The man who found his fate|language= Spanish|author= María Ana Rago|date= February 13, 2006|publisher= Clarín|accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref> The newspaper ''[[La Nación]]'' praised the show's mix of sitcom humor and telenovela drama, and equated the dramatic episodes to the works of renowned telenovela authors [[Abel Santa Cruz]], [[Alberto Migré]], and Delia Fiallo.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/838156-escenas-para-derretir-la-nieve|title= Escenas para derretir la nieve|trans-title= Scenes to melt the snow|language= Spanish|author= Natalia Trzenko|date= September 6, 2006|work= La Nación|accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref>
The program was criticized for the length of time{{mdash}}nearly three months{{mdash}}before the lead couple's first kiss.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://edant.clarin.com/diario/2006/04/05/conexiones/t-01171611.htm|title= Te beso en el capítulo 3.583: cuando crear expectativa es un recurso tan exitoso como repetido|trans-title= I will kiss you on the 3.583 episode: when building expectations is a resource as successful as repeated|language= Spanish|author= Lorena Bassani|date= April 5, 2006|publisher= Clarín|accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref> Clarín also criticized a badly-performed striptease act by Facundo Arana.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://edant.clarin.com/diario/2006/03/15/conexiones/t-01158996.htm |title= Facundo Arana hizo un striptease para Natalia Oreiro |trans-title= Facundo Arana made a strptease for Natalia Oreiro|language= Spanish|author= Leonardo Bachanian|date= March 15, 2006|publisher= Clarín|accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref> As Carlos Belloso could not go with Arana and Oreiro to the filming at the World Cup, he was filmed in the [[Plaza San Martín (Buenos Aires)|Plaza San Martín]], pretending that he was in Germany as well.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://edant.clarin.com/diario/2006/06/20/conexiones/t-01219129.htm|title= Sos mi birra: Natalia Oreiro y Facundo Arana también viajaron al mundial|trans-title= You Are My Beer: Natalia Oreiro and Facundo Arana visited the World Cup too|language= Spanish|author= Leonardo Bachanian|date= June 20, 2006|publisher= Clarín|accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref>
The program's scheduled broadcast time was 21:00, but the channel often delayed its broadcast by up to 40 minutes. This led to conflicts with other channels and COMFER, the institution that regulates Argentine television.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/871641-la-dictadura-de-los-horarios|title= La dictadura de los horarios|trans-title= The dictatorship of the hours|language= Spanish|author= Verónica Bonacchi|date= December 31, 2006|work= La Nación|accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/846805-canal-13-en-medio-de-la-encrucijada-del-rating|title= Canal 13, en medio de la encrucijada del rating|trans-title= Channel 13, amid the labirinth of rating|language= Spanish|author= Natalia Trzenko|date= October 6, 2006|work= La Nación|accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref> The last episode lasted for half an hour and was followed by the premiere of the new telenovela ''[[Son de Fierro]]''; La Nación said that the final episode should have lasted a full hour.<ref name="amor"/>
==Airings and remakes== The program was initially aired in Argentina in 2006 on [[El Trece (Argentina)|El Trece]] at [[prime time]]. Following the success of the initial run, El Trece and ''Volver'' reran the show. It is sold internationally by the [[Dori Media Group]] under the English name "You Are The One" to more than 40 countries.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://edant.clarin.com/diario/2007/03/21/espectaculos/c-01384313.htm|title= Natalia Oreiro, a Cannes por "Sos mi vida"|trans-title= Natalia Oreiro, to Cannes for "You Are the One"|language= Spanish|date= March 21, 2007|publisher= Clarín|accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref>
The concept of the program was sold as well, and some countries remade the telenovela with local actors. The Mexican version, ''[[Un gancho al corazón]]'', starred [[Danna Garcia]], [[Sebastián Rulli]], [[Laisha Wilkins]], and [[Raul Araiza]]. The characters were renamed, but Garcia's character retained the sobriquet "La Monita". The Polish version, ''[[Prosto w serce]]'', starred [[Anna Mucha]], Filip Bobek, and [[Małgorzata Socha]]. The Portuguese version, ''[[Deixa-me amar]]'', starred [[Paulo Pires]] and Paula Lobo Antunes.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.zapping-tv.com/tvi-volta-a-emitir-deixa-me-amar/|title= TVI volta a emitir "Deixa-me Amar"|trans-title= TVI airs again "Deixa-me Amar"|language= Portuguese|date= May 9, 2012|publisher= Clarín|accessdate=July 10, 2013}}</ref>
